General course objectives:
General course objectives
To give the practical background for formulation and numerical solution of general turbulent flow problems, including classical wall resolved and wall modeled channel flows and synthetic turbulence generation using computational fluid dynamics (CFD) techniques.
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
Describe fundamentals of Computational Fluid Dynamics
Explain the main features of turbulent flows
Analyse governing Navier-Stokes equations
Differentiate between turbulence models for different flow applications
Develop simple 1D turbulent flow solvers using Matlab/Python
Explain synthetic turbulence generation in LES
Use OpenFOAM to solve fluid flows
Apply best practices in scientific report writing
Content:
Historical background, basics of CFD and turbulence modeling, characteristics and
scales of turbulent motions in fluids
Taxonomy of turbulence models
Time-averaged and spatially filtered governing equations
Introdution to Burger’s turbulence
Reynolds-Averaged Navier Stokes (RANS) modeling
Eddy-viscosity (Algebraic-, 1- and 2-equation) models
Large Eddy Simulation (LES): (Filtering, Sub-grid scale (SGS) modeling)
Generation of synthetic turbulence
Wall bounded flows
Course literature:
Kajishima, T. and Taira, K., 2016. Computational fluid dynamics: incompressible turbulent flows. Springer.

Reif, B.P. and Durbin, P.A., 2011. Statistical theory and modeling for turbulent flows. John Wiley & Sons.

Various notes and book chapters will be provided during the course as needed.
